questions.question: Which of the following statements does not belong in the definition of nation?

choices.answer: A nation is a people who feel a sense of belonging together
Nation comes from the Latin word meaning “people” or “race.”
A nation needs a defined geographic region
A nation is a people who want to control their own destiny

questions.question: Which of the traits below is not necessarily part of a civic nation?

choices.answer: shared values and beliefs
equality of rights and responsibilities
acceptance of cultural and religious diversity
a common language and ethnicity

questions.question: Ethnic nationalism can divide people into “us” and “them.” This can lead to:

choices.answer: intolerance and conflict
a lack of patriotism
a multi-nation state
diversity and peaceful coexistance

questions.question: Which would be the best title for the diagram?

choices.answer: Requirements of a Nation-State
Building Blocks of a Civic Nation
Some Understandings of Nation
Building Blocks of an Ethnic Nation

questions.question: Parisians stormed the Bastille because they wanted to:

choices.answer: Free criminals imprisoned by the king.
Free prisoners unjustly imprisoned by the king.
Take action against the king and the local nobility.
Start a revolution and overthrow the king.

questions.question: The cartoon focuses on the idea that:

choices.answer: Division society into three Estates, peasants at the bottom.
Religious teachings of the Church about life after death.
The whole nation had to carry the monarch.
Those without fine clothing should do physical labour.

questions.question: One reason the Canadian government decided to relocate Inuit people in the 1930s was to

choices.answer: Provide them with the same rights as other Canadians.
Save their traditional way of life.
Save many Inuit from starvation
Establish the first reserves for Inuit people.

questions.question: The main reason many Aboriginal peoples became more politically involved in the 1970s was to

choices.answer: End treaty rights, reserves, payments, and resource rights.
Have the same status and rights as other Canadians.
Stop Québec separatism
Have greater control over their lives, education, and laws.

questions.question: A common feature of the Oka Crisis and the James Bay and Northern Québec Settlement was that

choices.answer: The issues were resolved peacefully without loss of life
Federal government responded by creating a royal commission
First Nations won some concessions from the federal gov't
Québec government refused to allow federal intervention

questions.question: The primary motivation for Québec’s passing Bill 101 was to

choices.answer: Prevent further erosion of French language and culture
Increase provincial power over immigration laws
Encourage Anglophones in to support French language schools
Provincial government’s policy to create a Francophone state

questions.question: The chart above represents which of the following events?

choices.answer: Quebecois Revolution
Quebec Provincial Election
Quebec Referendum on Reasonable Accommodations
Quebec Sovereignty Referendum

questions.question: The debate how much immigrants should fit into Canadian culture is referring to the concept of

choices.answer: Reasonable assimilation
Reasonable integration
Reasonable adaptation
Reasonable accommodation
Fall in the purchasing power of money
Decline in consumer prices
Rise in the purchasing power of money
Decline in house prices

questions.question: The statement “I am an Albertan” indicates that the speaker has a

choices.answer: National loyalty
Regional loyalty
Cultural loyalty
Religious loyalty

questions.question: Until 1957, racial groups in the American South had/faced

choices.answer: Reconciled
Assimilated
Integrated
Segregation
